_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary	

In order to comply with the Risk Management Program regulations, 40 CFR Part 68, mandated under the accidental release provisions of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, the International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is submitting this Risk Management Plan for the East Fishkill Facility.

Hydrogen  and Ammonia at greater than 20% are  currently the only substances which are stored in quantities greater than the respective reporting thresholds and required to be included in this submission.  Ammonia at greater than 20% is stored at the Ammonia Treatment Plant and is covered by Prevention Program 2.  Hydrogen is currently stored in a single location within the facility and covered by Prevention Program 3. 
 
Prevention Program Level 2:  Ammonia Treatment Plant

The Process Hazard Review (PHR) Team for Ammonia Treatment Plant is comprised of the following: Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer (team leader), Safety representative, Treatment Plant operator, Controls Technician, and Design Firm representatives.  The results of each PHR are recorded and maintained on file.

Operating procedures for the Ammonia Treatment Plant were originally written by the manufacturer and design firms, with input from Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer and involved employees using technical process descriptions and process safety information.  Operating procedures, as specified in the Ammonia Treatment Plant Operations O+ M Manual are available from Environmental Regulatory Engineering D/9XMA and Environmental Engineering and Operations, D/92D.

Training for the Ammonia Treatment Plant Operation is formulated and tracked by the  Ammonia Treatment Plant Engineer and training records are maintained by managers of D/9XMA and D92D.

Incident investigation program follows the IBM incident report procedure in the Safety & Health Manual for fact determination, root cause analysis and recommendation implementation.

A maximum of 150,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia (25%) are in

ventoried as a result of reclaiming dilute aqueous ammonia to produce a  product. 

The toxic end point from a worse case  release of  aqueous ammonia has been calculated to be 3.4 miles using the RMP*Comp model.

The toxic end point from an alternative release case of aqueous ammonia has been calculated to be 0.6 miles  using the RMP*Comp model.

Release prevention of aqueous ammonia includes the use of automatic shutoff, interlocks, alarms and procedures.  Operator refresher training and system update training are conducted as prescribed in the operator training program.  All incidents are investigated to determine root cause and system deficiency correction.

No accidents/incidents have occurred  involving The Ammonia Treatment Plant in the past 5 years.

IBM is currently scheduled to complete upgrades to Ammonia Treatment Plant by 12/31/2008 as recommended by the Process Hazard Review dated 12/06/2007. 

Prevention Program Level 3:  Hydrogen Storage

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for Hydrogen Storage is conducted on a five year schedule by the Process Hazard Analysis Team.  The PHA team for Hydrogen is comprised of the following: Gas Engineer (team leader), Safety representative for gases, Gas Technician, representatives from site manufacturing organizations, Emergency Control representative, and Air Products (Vendor Engineer). 

Operating procedures for Hydrogen Storage were written by the Gas Engineer using technical process descriptions and process safety information, and with input from the involved employees.  Operating procedures, as specified in the Process Safety Management (PSM) Documentation for the Hydrogen System, are available from Site Gas Operations (D/01EA).  The operating procedures are documented as Bulk Gas Procedures or as Desk References.. 

Training for Hydrogen Storage formulated and tracked by the Gas Engineer and training records are maintained by the manager of D/01EA.
  
Incident investigation program follows the IBM incident report

procedure in the Safety & Health Manual Index for fact determination, root cause analysis and recommendation implementation.

Mechanical Integrity for Hydrogen Storage is shared between the gas supplier and IBM.  The program consists of equipment lists and specifications, equipment history, and preventative maintenance procedures. 

Hot work permits for work on the hydrogen system are issued by IBM (Emergency Control) or Air Products.  These permit issuing processes includes a safety inspection of  the area.  

Quality assurance of the Management of Change (MOC) program for Hydrogen is provided  by the Hydrogen Storage Process Safety Management (PSM) Owner.  The MOC is composed of a written program with elements delegated to appropriate members of the PSM team.  A copy of the documentation is maintained for the life of the process. 

Quality assurance of the hydrogen pre-startup review program is provided by the Hydrogen Storage  PSM Owner.  Documentation is maintained as part the MOC program.  

A Maximum of 44,000 lbs of hydrogen is inventoried to produce semiconductor and related products.

The overpressure end point from a worse case release of hydrogen has been calculated to be 0.3 miles  using the RMP*Comp model.

The overpressure end point from the alternate release case  for hydrogen has been calculated to be 0.2 miles using the RMP*Comp model.

Release prevention of hydrogen includes the use of mass flow monitoring, automatic shutoff valves, interlocks, alarms and procedures.  Operator refresher training and system update training are conducted as prescribed in the operator training program.  The maintenance program inspections and tests are performed to assure operation of the prevention devices.  Management of change is monitored by the Process Safety Management Coordinator to assure the program is updated and implemented according to the corporate standards for design and operations.  All incidents are investigated to determine root cause and system defi

ciency corrections.

No accidents/incidents have occurred  involving hydrogen in the past 5 years.

IBM has implemented all safety improvements which were identified in previous PSA for Hydrogen Storage.

The Facility emergency response plan defines response organizations, coordination with local emergency responders, equipment, response procedures, training, notifications procedures and drills.  The plan is updated according to the recommendations resulting from system deficiencies identified by periodic drills.
